Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now produce a final answer accordingly.</think>One acceptable way to “extract” an f‐value from each key is to write it in the form

  key = f(n) · n + (remainder)

so that when you “divide” the key by its index n the quotient is f(n) and the leftover is a remainder. (In some cases more than one representation is possible; see the note below on k₁₂.)

For example, suppose we are given these keys:

 • k₇ = 76  
 • k₈ = 224  
 • k₉ = 467  
 • k₁₁ = 1155  
 • k₁₂ can be written either as 223×12 + 7 or, “by design”, as k₈×12 – 5 (since k₈ = 224).

Then we may proceed as follows:

1. For n = 7, write
  76 = 10·7 + 6.
Thus one takes f(7) = 10.

2. For n = 8,
  224 = 28·8 + 0.
So f(8) = 28.

3. For n = 9, note that
  467 = 51·9 + 8  (since 51×9 = 459 and 459+8 = 467).
Thus f(9) = 51.

4. For n = 11,
  1155 = 105·11 + 0.
So f(11) = 105.

5. Finally, for n = 12 there is a little ambiguity. One may “divide” in the usual way:
  2683 = 223·12 + 7  (since 223×12 = 2676 and 2676+7 = 2683),
so one possibility is f(12) = 223.
However, the puzzle also singles out an alternative representation,
  2683 = (k₈)·12 – 5 = 224·12 – 5  (since k₈ = 224 and 224×12 = 2688, so 2688–5 = 2683),
which shows that one may also take f(12) = 224.
In many such puzzles the “nice” answer is to take the representation that uses an earlier key (here, k₈); thus one acceptable answer is f(12)=224.

Note. The key k₅ happens not to be given in a form of “f(n)·n + …” at all but rather as a product (k₂ × k₃). In our discussion we are only “extracting” f‐values from the keys that are written in the linear form.

To summarize, one acceptable answer is:

 • f(7) = 10  
 • f(8) = 28  
 • f(9) = 51  
 • f(11) = 105  
 • f(12) can be taken as either 223 (if you write 2683 = 223×12 + 7) or 224 (using the representation 2683 = k₈×12 – 5).

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.
